topics.body:
Now that I look back at it. American cartoons from the 70s really were total garbage for the most part. (That time when scooby clones were everywhere)

70s Anime completely outclassed most of what we got.

Now I'm not saying that anime in general is better than american shows.

But for that decade, We got Scooby doo knockoffs, Super friends, And a lot of half assed looking celebrity cartoons.

And they had stuff like Gatchaman, Casshan, Yatterman, Mazinger Z, Getter robo, Raideen, Captain Harlock, Galaxy express 999, Space battleship Yamato, The robot romance trilogy, Aim for the ace, Doraemon, Lupin the third, And of course Mobile suit gundam.

topics.body:
"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e3486368725656573400#post_5561e3486368725656573400
The closer to the speed of light a body goes the slower it own clock becomes. This is so that nothing could travel faster than the speed of light. 

Actually, you can 'travel though time' by going just below the speed of light. Doing so would slow down your time while your surroundings flow by at normal speed. By your perspective, everything goes by really fast. So when you stop moving you find yourself in the future.

Traveling to the past is impossible by this logic though.
topics.author: 52f0834d63687261cba90300

topics.body:
"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e3486368725656573400#post_5561e3486368725656573400
[bq="HJSDGCE"]"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e04e6368721b82ff0b00#post_5561e04e6368721b82ff0b00
I want to believe that there are things moving faster than light and that going faster than light does NOT enable time travel. 
Which is against Einstein's theories.

And I do.[/bq]
 
T'=1/((1-sqrt(v²/c²)) If v>c than 1-(n>1) will equal a negative number and u cant square root a negative number and if v=c then v/c=1 1-1=0 sqrt of 0 is 0 1/0 is indef.
topics.author: 37e5b9d66361642500af5e00

topics.body:
"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e3486368725656573400#post_5561e3486368725656573400
Also, Einstein's theory dictates that nothing in this universe is faster than the speed of light. Nothing in this universe... let that sink in a bit.
topics.author: 52f0834d63687261cba90300

topics.body:
"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e5596368722df2d60200#post_5561e5596368722df2d60200
[bq="Kaz"]"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e3486368725656573400#post_5561e3486368725656573400
[bq="HJSDGCE"]"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e04e6368721b82ff0b00#post_5561e04e6368721b82ff0b00
I want to believe that there are things moving faster than light and that going faster than light does NOT enable time travel. 
Which is against Einstein's theories.

And I do.[/bq]
 
T'=1/((1-sqrt(v²/c²)) If v>c than 1-(n>1) will equal a negative number and u cant square root a negative number and if v=c then v/c=1 1-1=0 sqrt of 0 is 0 1/0 is indef. [/bq]

Then there is time dilation by gravity which is 

T'=1/(1-(sqrt(2GM/C²d))

G is Newton's Gravitational Constant, M is the mass of the body that is doing the dialting and d is how far away that object is from that body.

2GM/C² is called the Schawrzchild radius. It gives you the size an object would have to be to have a gravitational pull strong enough to prevent light from escaping from it

topics.body:
"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e6586368721b82f61300#post_5561e6586368721b82f61300
[bq="Kaz"]"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e5596368722df2d60200#post_5561e5596368722df2d60200
[bq="Kaz"]"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e3486368725656573400#post_5561e3486368725656573400
[bq="HJSDGCE"]"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e04e6368721b82ff0b00#post_5561e04e6368721b82ff0b00
I want to believe that there are things moving faster than light and that going faster than light does NOT enable time travel. 
Which is against Einstein's theories.

And I do.[/bq]
 
T'=1/((1-sqrt(v²/c²)) If v>c than 1-(n>1) will equal a negative number and u cant square root a negative number and if v=c then v/c=1 1-1=0 sqrt of 0 is 0 1/0 is indef. [/bq] the closer you are to the speed of light, even @ 100 mph time will be moving slower for you than the outside world

Then there is time dilation by gravity which is 

T'=1/(1-(sqrt(2GM/C²d))

G is Newton's Gravitational Constant, M is the mass of the body that is doing the dialting and d is how far away that object is from that body.

2GM/C² is called the Schawrzchild radius. It gives you the size an object would have to be to have a gravitational pull strong enough to prevent light from escaping from it
[/bq]

topics.body:
"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e6f16368722df2ca0400#post_5561e6f16368722df2ca0400
[bq="Kaz"]"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e6586368721b82f61300#post_5561e6586368721b82f61300
[bq="Kaz"]"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e5596368722df2d60200#post_5561e5596368722df2d60200
[bq="Kaz"]"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e3486368725656573400#post_5561e3486368725656573400
[bq="HJSDGCE"]"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e04e6368721b82ff0b00#post_5561e04e6368721b82ff0b00
I want to believe that there are things moving faster than light and that going faster than light does NOT enable time travel. 
Which is against Einstein's theories.

And I do.[/bq]
 
T'=1/((1-sqrt(v²/c²)) If v>c than 1-(n>1) will equal a negative number and u cant square root a negative number and if v=c then v/c=1 1-1=0 sqrt of 0 is 0 1/0 is indef. [/bq] the closer you are to the speed of light, even @ 100 mph time will be moving slower for you than the outside world

Then there is time dilation by gravity which is 

T'=1/(1-(sqrt(2GM/C²d))

G is Newton's Gravitational Constant, M is the mass of the body that is doing the dialting and d is how far away that object is from that body.

2GM/C² is called the Schawrzchild radius. It gives you the size an object would have to be to have a gravitational pull strong enough to prevent light from escaping from it
[/bq]
[/bq]

Even if you're walking, time is moving slower for you, even if the effects seem detrimental. 

Satellites have to recalibrated each year due to time dilation.

"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5561e7886368721b82141600#post_5561e7886368721b82141600
Interesting how that works. The faster you move, the slower your own 'clock' becomes. This is to ensure nothing in this universe could move faster than the speed of light.
